comments.commentBody: I hope that President Obama will also grant pardons to:  John Walker Lindh, Edward Snowden and of course Chelsea Manning.  The sentences and circumstances of each of these people have been more than sufficient punishment and retribution for their "crimes against the state." Anything more would constitute "cruel and unusual punishment" and contravene our Constitution. Enough is enough. They all deserve our mercy and forgiveness.
If I were president Obama, I would finally tell the American public how I actually felt about them, and make it much easier for Trump's incomprehensible policies to destroy them.

( Symbolically ) President Obama should make a big show of pardoning republicans for their ''treasonous'' action over the last 8 years.

Just like he pardons a turkey.

I haven't seen any mention of Leonard Peltier or Mumia in these comments.  Is that because no commenter thinks they should be released, or because these folks are just not "on anyone's radar" anymore?  Wondering...
So you the NYT know better than juries and judges?  I  would observe that you actually know nothing about the subject and should stop publishing opinions that are not thoroughly reviewed.

According to NIJ, the following Statistics obtain with regard to recidivism among all released offenders in general, and among drug offenders in particularThe researchers found that:

Within three years of release, about two-thirds (67.8 percent) of released prisoners were rearrested.
Within five years of release, about three-quarters (76.6 percent) of released prisoners were rearrested.
Of those prisoners who were rearrested, more than half (56.7 percent) were arrested by the end of the first year.
Property offenders were the most likely to be rearrested, with 82.1 percent of released property offenders arrested for a new crime compared with 76.9 percent of drug offenders, 73.6 percent of public order offenders and 71.3 percent of violent offenders.

With 77% of released drug offenders recidivating in the same year or within a few years, there is no sense is showing mercy just to have those released persons getting rearrested.

Besides, many of those serving time are ILLEGAL ALIENS caught for peddling drugs. Unless you advocate that they be deported to their country of origin, your pity is without merit.

Good thing Obama's DEA kept marijuana as a Schedule I drug.

Can't have empty prisons now, can we?
I honestly don't think "mercy" is in Obama's emotional vocabulary. He's far too much of a cold fish.

The Editorial Board's articles are becoming nauseating, insofar as they absolutely relentlessly speculate on the likely doom and gloom of the Trump administration. Even an article like this, seemingly about the Obama presidency, can't help but include yet another jab at Trump ("prospects under the next administration don’t look good. President-elect Donald Trump ran on a “law and order” platform that sounded a lot like the punitive approach..."). I used to look forward to the Board's articles, I thought that they were interesting and insightful. Now I feel like they are one big political pity party---a bunch of whining.

There are black men doing life for non-violent crimes (drugs)and violent people getting out every day???

Something is out of whack here...

Bob
And where was HE when the DAPL was being built??????? All done during HIS tenure as POTUS. Silent as usual and hypocritical.

Chelsea Manning.

Snowden if that is possible
He should start by pardoning anyone doing time for any kind of non-violent marijuana conviction.
Clemency is a good idea, but blanket commutations is not.

My 2 cents:
Hillary
Snowden
Chelsea
Every child born on US soil to "illegal" immigrants.
Commuting their sentences to what they would have been serving under the now-revised sentencing standards makes obvious sense.  To do otherwise is, on its face, cruel.

A real act of political courage would be grant those pardons one the first day in office or the week before re-election.  Pardoning criminals on the way out the door signals that the president believes in those pardons only to the degree that he will face no consequences--a viewpoint unlikely to be shared by the future victims of the saintly figures the New York Times would like to see roaming the streets.

I wonder if President Obama can finally develop a backbone, and pardon all low-level drug offenders, plus any and all individuals, in whatever prison, county, state, federal, and military, for minor non-violent crimes, and all pardons gramted, must expunge the criminal record of these people, so they have a chance to begin anew.

Chelsea Manning, and our too long ignored hero, Edward Snowden, must also be pardoned.

As a former Obama supporter, one who came to know how ineffective he has been these last wasted 8 years in office, I have no hope he will do that which is right and just, and instead will choose the ho-hum, lackadaisical path, fearful of angering his masters.

replies.commentBody: Cannibis hasn't been legalized on a Federal level or in many, if not most, states including New York.  Just because the late Brooklyn DA said his office would no longer prosecute those offenses, or some of them, does not mean it is now legal in Manhattan Beach or anywhere else in Brooklyn, the City or State. It would be a shame if you found yourself incarcerated based on this mis-information.

comments.commentBody:
Anyone who is now in prison for possession, use, furnishing or even selling marijuana should be released. It is not now a crime and it never should have been. The laws regarding marijuana destroyed more lives than any use of it ever did or ever will. For possession, 1 to 10 years. Parole was a dream. I knew many people who did every day of 10 years for having a a few joints in their possession. 5 to life for selling or "furnishing" that is giving marijuana to some one. People have done 20, 30 years in prison. It cost us on average 31,286$.
The marijuana laws were designed to provide a raw material stream for the prison business. It was never about freedom and justice for all.

President Obama needs to release all inmates that are low-mid level offenders. Sentencing standards that have been in place are biased against anyone who is not white. We would see a totally different narrative of who should be released if this was a majority white population. We would also see a different velocity of releases if the majority were white.
President Obama needs to take a humanitarian stance and free our current day slaves. What an awesome legacy to leave office on.

The American gulag archipelago is as obscene as its Stalinist predecessor.
To move to civilized norms Obama should free 80 per cent of prisoners older than 60 and half of prisoners who are been held for non-violent offences.
The two major sources of theft today are tax evasion and corporate corruption. There is nothing as effective as prison for curbing plutocratic criminals.
Have the crooked banksters and billionaires serve five year sentences for their huge crimes, including a 60 day stint in solitary.
The biggest thieves in America still lord it over us. Once they are jailbirds with 10,000 people waiting to sue them, maybe they will be less of a model for larcenous youth.

Of course it's the right thing to do - moral, decent. Some other people should also be included like Snowden and Manning to name just 2 more. Yet, in 8 years, I can't think of a single instance where Obama showed any mercy or compassion toward anyone who "broke the law" or "made a mistake" - nor anyone suffering through hard times, or foreclosed on or buried in student loan debt or literally unable to get the medical care they needed when they needed it.

Yes, more recently he's signed on for some clemency of some fortunate people. I wonder how much of that has to do with his shaky legacy in the waning days of this disappointing presidency.

No, in 8 years, Obama has looked upon his subjects in the U.S. antiseptically, scoldingly, determining if people were quite worthy enough for help or aid and then it might come in some form in time, down the line, incrementally. In addition there has always been the political calculation - as with gay marriage. If it serves him politically or in the eyes of the folks he hangs out with who might care about liberal issues, then maybe he'll step it up, but I wouldn't hold my breath.

I hold out little hope that he'll do anything of any great import on the side of justice or morality. He's shown an aversion during most of his presidency to actions based on those very things. Talks about it, but does little if anything.

I agree 100%. And while you are at it Mr. President, I request you pardon Mrs. Clinton. I don't think she has done anything wrong but Trump and his minions are too unstable to trust. A suggestion:

President Obama is requested to pardon Mrs. Clinton from any crimes, misdemeanors or violations of law arising out of or in connection with her service as Secretary of State and/or in connection with or arising out of her testimony before Congress or otherwise regarding her service as Secretary or her use of a private email server, because certain individuals who may have influence in the Trump administration have suggested they may pursue criminal charges against her. The only way to prevent such harassment is a pardon.
First on that list should be Bradley Manning.

replies.commentBody:
Free OSCAR LÓPEZ RIVERA, Obama san !

Let's make a powerful statement against the United States of Prisons.

Go, Bobby !

comments.commentBody:
One of the longest serving being OSCAR LÓPEZ RIVERA, a Puerto Rican nationalist age 73, longest-incarcerated FALN member sentenced to 70 years for Seditious conspiracy,

At age 18 he was drafted into the army and served in the Vietnam War and awarded the Bronze Star.

López Rivera was among the 14 convicted FALN members offered conditional clemency by U.S. President Bill Clinton in 1999, but rejected the offer. He refused the offer because on parole, he would be in "prison outside prison." Resident Commissioner, Pedro Pierluisi, has stated that "the primary reason that López Rivera did not accept the clemency offer extended to him in 1999 was because it had not also been extended to fellow FALN prisoner Carlos Torres (who was subsequently released from prison in July 2010)."

PRESIDENT CLINTON and others defended this offer of clemency, stating that Oscar López Rivera WAS NEVER CONVICTED OF SPECIFIC CRIMESTHAT RESULTED IN DEATHS OR INURIES and that López Rivera WAS NEVER CONVICTED OF ANY CRIME OF VIOLENCE.*

On 16 May 2016 Vermont SENATOR BERNIE SANDERS publicly tweeted, "Oscar Lopez Rivera has served 34 years in prison for his commitment to Puerto Rico's independence. I say to President Obama: let him out."

I too say to President Obama, before you leave the White House, SEND OSCAR LÓPEZ RIVERA HOME TO PUERTO RICO!

* Wikipedia; UPPER CASE mine for EMPHASIS only.
